Award.AwardTitle: Multiscalar Approach to the Study of Vegetation and Plant Use during the Neolithic Period in the Central Balkans: A Case Study from the Vinca Settlement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Borojevic in collaboration with a multidisciplinary international team will study plant remains to reveal plant use and vegetation exploitation related to the built-environments at the Vinca site, a type site of the Neolithic culture in Serbia in Southeast Europe. The site provides an exceptional opportunity for the study of economic production and building practices in the fifth millennia BC in the central Balkans, a core area from which settled agricultural communities expanded into the Carpathian Basin in the prehistory. The study will provide the initial data on past vegetation and possible changes in the environment of central Southeast Europe and use of space in the past 7000 years. The project will contribute to the precise determination of the functions of the buildings, their life histories, the overall function of the site and the use of plants and the exploitation of natural vegetation during the late Neolithic.

This research is important because it will help to establish novel techniques and methodology of identifying minute plant remains, an approach which can then be expanded and applied to the study of vegetal matter world-wide, regardless of the period and type of deposit.

Dr Borojevic will develop sample collection/preparation procedures which will serve as a test case for assessing accurate, well-contextualized information produced by combining micromorphological data (thin-sections) with those of bulk flotation of plant remains from similar proveniences. The purpose is to reveal the types of plants used for fuel, construction, fodder, and bedding, and how their use changed spatially (ca. 4500 BC). Together with direct radiocarbon dating, plant remains in thin sections can provide high resolution, contextually controlled views of anthropogenic deposits and post-depositional histories regarding vegetal matter and human activities. The combined information gained from the analyses will enable reconstruction of the ancient vegetation and the ecological conditions around the site in order to understand better the strategies people employ in exploiting the natural vegetation and the choices they make when using diverse plant materials for construction of different features, types of fuel, or fodder.

The project will promote collaboration and cross training amongst scholars and dissemination of the new technique to the graduate and undergraduate students in the USA and Serbia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The  initial objectives of the project ?Multiscalar Approach to the Study of Vegetation and Plant Use during the Neolithic Period in the Central Balkans: A Case Study from the Vinca Settlement? were to investigate to reveal plant use and vegetation exploitation related to the built-environments in the well-excavated tell site Vinca-Belo Brdo, near Belgrade in Serbia. During the investigations, our research expanded beyond the original goals to include additional architectural and site formation details generated from the geoarchaeological research. The attention to microstratigraphy was especially important in understanding periodicity and construction variability in the densely built landscape of the late Neolithic settlement.

The intellectual merit of the project includes examination of plant preservation, deposition, and use. We developed and refined the analytical technique for identification of minute plant remains from petrographic thin sections of undisturbed samples, in particular wood, stems, leaves, aand seeds. This demonstrates not only that plants may be successfully assigned taxonomically based on incomplete evidence but that context of plant remains can be studied within microstratigraphy.

The project research included palaeoethnobotanical and micromorophological studies accompanied with direct AMS dating. The study revealed depositional and post-depositional processes and past human activities related to the exploitation and use of plants and use of vegetation. The combined approach provided the opportunity to examine economic production and building practices and determined the use of materials, building techniques, life-histories of buildings, and use of space within the late Neolithic settlement and its environs.

The broader impacts of this project are multiple. We established and refined identification of minute plant remains from micromorphological thin sections which can be expanded and applied to the study of vegetal matter world-wide, regardless of the period and type of deposit. The data gathered are especially useful to other projects studying early urban sites  in southeast Europe and further afield. During the project, the collaboration was promoted to graduate and undergraduate students. The field and laboratory  techniques were demonstrated and cross-training was implemented among scholars and students from various institutions and universities in the USA and Serbia. Publications of articles in international scholarly journals and public lectures have and will continue to advance the scientific and technological advantages of combining micromorphology and plant analysis to address questions related to the development and site formation of early urban settlements.
